intro: Gilia tweedyi, commonly known as Tweedy's gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and clusters of small, showy flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically blooms in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in sandy or rocky soils and is often found in dry, open habitats. Gilia tweedyi is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton.
